Send shutdown and Wake-on-LAN commands to computers within your local network.

Based on \'Wake on Lan\' by Mr.Webb and \'Remote Shutdown\' by Isah Rikovic as an all-in-one Android/Kotlin learning exercise. Both apps are available on Google Play.

To use the remote shutdown feature and get device\'s hostname and MAC, please download the Remote PC Control Tray.

Due to Android security restrictions since Android 13+ is not longer possible to ping or query ARP table to get status/hostname and MAC address of target device. This means that for scanning a trial and error approach has to be used querying some known TCP ports usually opened in the target device OS.

In case that Remote PC Control Tray is running in the computer, as the first try is to reach its listening port it will return both computer hostname and its MAC address. Otherwise, neither the hostname nor MAC address will be returned and they will need to be entered manually.
Device scan doesn\'t find my devices

Firstly, make sure that your devices are turned on. Device scanning will only work for devices that are turned on.

Scanning can sometimes miss a device if it does not respond quickly enough to connection attempt. Trying again or setting a higher timeout may pick up those missing devices. If not detected in any way, you can always add it manually.

Read the Known limitations section for more information about this.

‚ö† Setting timeout too low may cause scan to miss devices; setting it too high may delay scanning.
Device status is wrong or inconsistent

Sometimes the status shown in the main screen device list is wrong or does not match the actual device status. This can be caused by the Known limitations and/or by modern OS/BIOS energy saving management.

It has been observed strange behaviours when a device is in suspension or hibernation leading to being able to access ports that in other systems are not available and vice-versa, and showing an incorrect status. It seems to depend on vendors.

For devices showing as off when they\'re turned on, one common cause is the use of router\'s DHCP automatic IP assignment. When using DHCP, the once added device may have been assigned a different IP address, showing itself as turned off.

To deal with this, either change device IP manually in the app or just assign a static IP address for the device in the router so it will be always the same.

Privacy

This app does not collect, store, or transmit any personal data.

It does not use cookies, analytics, tracking technologies, or any external services that could identify you.

All information handled by the app (such as saved devices or configuration preferences) is stored locally on your device only, using Android\'s standard storage mechanisms (SharedPreferences/DataStore). These data never leave your phone and can be removed at any time by uninstalling the app.

The app does not request any special permissions beyond what is strictly necessary for its functionality, and it does not connect to any external servers other than the one you configure yourself.
